column1: King of the Noldor was a title held by some of the rulers of the Noldor
column2: though others used the title High King of the Noldor.
that part of the Tatyar Elves who participated in the Great Journey
column3: were led by Finwë. Finwë was one of the three elves summoned to Valinor by Oromë to serve as messengers to their fellows
column4: and later became the ruler of the Noldor in Valinor
column5: who lived in the city of Tirion. He was known as the King of the Noldor
column6: and had three sons from two marriages.

column1: Finwë followed his eldest son Fëanor into exile at Formenos
column2: and was killed by Morgoth following the Darkening of Valinor. Following his fathers death
column3: Fëanor returned to Tirion even though the Valar had not lifted his exile. This cast Fëanors inheritance of the kingship into question
column4: but the rhetorical skill of Fëanor convinced the majority of the Noldor to follow him in his Flight of the Noldor against the Valar
repented of the rebellion and was permitted to return to Tirion because his people had played no part in the Kinslaying. He subsequently became the King of the Noldor in Valinor. However

column2: Fingolfin was named King of the Noldor in Beleriand. With the establishment of many different Noldorin realms
column3: this title soon became High King of the Noldor in Middle-earth. Following Fingolfins death in the Dagor Bragollach
column4: the title passed to his son Fingon. Following Fingons death in the Nirnaeth Arnoediad
column5: the title passed to his younger brother Turgon.

column1: Following Turgons death in the Fall of Gondolin
column2: there were no more extant Noldorin realms in Beleriand. However
column3: the young Gil-galad was named High King once news of Turgons death had spread. In the published version of The Silmarillion
column4: Gil-galad is said to be the son of Fingon. However
column5: in some of Tolkiens later notes
column6: published in The History of Middle-earth
column7: Gil-galad is said to be the son of Orodreth and thus a junior member of the House of Finarfin
column8: and Turgons closest living relative in the male line (excluding the dispossessed House of Fëanor).

column1: After the cataclysmic War of Wrath that ended the First Age
column2: the surviving Noldor who did not depart for the Undying Lands constituted the realms of Lindon and Eregion in northwestern Middle-earth. Gil-galad continued to reign as High King
column3: though as in the First Age this title brought little real authority beyond the kings own direct realm. However
column4: Gil-galad was the commander of almost all of the Elven forces who fought in the War of the Last Alliance.

column1: After Gil-galads death in that war
column2: the title of High King was no longer used. He had fathered no children
column3: and there were no other male line descendants of Finwë living in Middle-earth at that time. The Noldorin population of Middle-earth was greatly diminished in the Third Age
column4: but Elrond functioned in a similar role to Gil-galad throughout the Age.

column1: ===High King of the Noldor in Middle-earth===
